name: Acoustic Blues
description: Developed out of Work Songs and Spirituals to become the most prominent early form of Blues.

children.name: Acoustic Chicago Blues
children.description: Unplugged Blues made in the Chicago region, primarily during the 1930s and 1940s.

children.name: Acoustic Texas Blues
children.description: Laid-back swing rhythms and guitar ornamentation, including solos.

children.name: Jug Band
children.description: Usually features a jug as the bass instrument as well as other homemade (or easily affordable) instruments, such as kazoos and washboards.

children.name: Piedmont Blues
children.description: Developed in the early 20th century in the southern Appalachian foothills and characterized by a syncopated but melodic Ragtime-based finger-picking acoustic guitar style.

name: Boogie Woogie
description: Early, uptempo Blues featuring the piano as the main instrument, with soloing and improvisation played over the top of a repetitive eight note bassline.

name: Country Blues
description: Various styles of Blues originating in the rural US South, typically relying on expressive vocal delivery and featuring simple, usually acoustic instrumentation.

children.name: Acoustic Texas Blues
children.description: Laid-back swing rhythms and guitar ornamentation, including solos.

children.name: Delta Blues
children.description: One of the earliest forms of Blues, named for the Mississippi Delta region of the United States where it developed, with a highly rhythmic style and a typical 12-bar structure.

children.name: Hill Country Blues
children.description: Emphasizes a steady hypnotic groove, sparse percussive and highly energetic guitar riffs, and often features meandering structures with unconventional and usually fewer chord changes compared to Delta Blues.

children.name: Piedmont Blues
children.description: Developed in the early 20th century in the southern Appalachian foothills and characterized by a syncopated but melodic Ragtime-based finger-picking acoustic guitar style.

name: Electric Blues
description: Major development in sound and reach of Blues when it became possible to amplify the instruments of small combos.

children.name: British Blues
children.description: Heavily influenced by the burgeoning United States Blues scene, particularly Chicago Blues.

children.name: Chicago Blues
children.description: Emerging in the 1940s, the prototypical and most influential form of Electric Blues on contemporary Blues, Blues Rock and Rock in general.

children.name: Electric Texas Blues
children.description: Originating in (but not limited to) Texas; includes Jazz influences like Swing rhythms and sometimes the addition of a horn section.

children.name: Swamp Blues
children.description: Originated in Baton Rouge, Louisiana in the 1950s, with a laid-back and relaxed sound that takes influence from Zydeco and Cajun Music.

name: Fife and Drum Blues
description: Rooted in martial Fife and Drum Corps music, originated among Afro-American communities in Mississippi.

name: Jump Blues
description: Emerged in the late 1930s with influence from jazz styles such as Swing and Big Band, featuring fast tempos and raucous performances.

name: New Orleans Blues
description: Diverse scene in New Orleans since the beginning of the 20th century, commonly associated with a sound led by rollicking pianos with syncopated beats and backed by horns.

name: Piano Blues
description: Played either solo or with the piano as the lead instrument of a small combo performing slow or mid-tempo blues ballads, as opposed to the commonly fast-paced Boogie Woogie.

name: Soul Blues
description: Shares similarities with Soul and incorporates the eponymous soulful inflections of Gospel, Jump Blues and soul into the vocals.
